Habitat: dense macchia next to a dirt path; slightly inclined terrain, west aspect; sunny, warm, dry place; calcareous ground; partly protected from direct rain by canopies; average precipitations ~ 900-1000 mm/year, average temperature 13-15 deg C, elevations 100 m (340 feet), sub-Mediterranean phytogeographical region.

Substratum: Dead Fraxinus ornus branch.

Place: West island Krk, west of village Brzac, Kvarner bay, Adriatic Sea, Croatia EC.

Comment: Parmotrema perlatum is a common lichen on island Krk. It prefers branches of Quercus sp. trees; however, the specimen photographed was found on Fraxinus ornus branches and twigs. It is a sensitive species to pollution hence it is much rarer in populated regions of industrialized countries and already regionally extinct in some parts of Europe. Its lobes are thin, very wavy, with abundant soralia and scarce black cilia at the margins. Underside is black with simple rhizines in the center and tan-colored and bare at margins. Apothecia are generally considered very rare; however, this was not the case for this observation. The species has been traditionally used for medical purposes in India as a diuretic and headache relief. It has proven sedative and antibiotic effects (Ref.5). Many specimens have been observed at the place of this observation. Pictures show the lichen in moist state (except picture 1. in dry state).

results.notes:
The mycelium and subsequent current fruiting of Spring Agrocybe “came along for the ride” with alder chips I laid last Fall for all Rhododendron’s on our back botanical garden. The chips of alder have a very stable PH and are perfect for adding micronutrients and fertilizer.

The persistent cracking of caps, even with young specimens, time of year and occurrence and “machined looking” stations at the apex of stems are all indicative for Spring Agrocybe. Also, a very common feeder on bark chips in Sping gardens when folks all get to Sping cleaning and weeding. I estimate that other than Morchella species, the Sping agrocybe group, with all their varying morphologies and sizes are the second most ID requested species this time of year on most all PNW Facebook forums and iNaturalist.

I have noted blue hued chips that are in the mix, as well, implying a future fruiting for Chlorociboria cups will most likely be in the cards ;).

Low 60’s over the last week with mixed rain/sunshine here in Olympia, WA.

Spring Agrocybe are edible, but are not a species I would recommend for experimentation and or culinary pursuits due to easy confusion with similar, brown spored genus=eg=Hebeloma.

results.notes:
INITIAL POST: A grow kit purchased on 5/11/18 while promoting my book “Fungal Freedom-A Guide To Wild Mushrooms Of Washington State” at the Olympia Farmer’s Market. This new local company “Myco-up-rrhizal” do a fantastic job and my hope and prayer is that they have continued and future successes, both locally and abroad. A couple was asking questions regarding medicinal fungi, grow kits and preparations for fungi. I felt truly blessed and honored to be part of the conversation and ultimately promoted multiple sales for this company in the process of explaining growth habits, preparations, drying processes and medicinally valuable constituents for not only the varnished Ganoderma complex, but also for Trametes versicolor, Hericium and many other species that arose to the conversation while I was perusing their tables selection/offers. For only 20$ this kit accompanied me home and has been growing on the kitchen table at a steady and resulting handsome, evenly fruiting pace.

As seen on the bag, I cut an opening to introduce O2 on 5/15/18 and have been exposing the kit for 2 to 3hrs each day on a regular schedule. The less oxygen this species, and other varnished Ganoderma spp. receive the thinner and longer(antlered shaped) the fruiting bodies grow. In ancient China and Japan the “antlered form” of Reishi/Ling Chi were most sought after and revered, most noteably by the “Iron Emperor” Chin Chi HuangDI who as most folks know was obsessed with Taoist practices and consuming the 5 elements to achieve immortality. Unfortunately for Huangdi the “metal” elemental representative he would consume was liquid Mercury and was the ultimate cause for his demise…
Not only are the antlered form beautiful, but have higher concentrations of Terpenes, triterpenes, sterols, etc. The patent I published in 2015 for a different species-Laricifomes officinalis(Agarikon) was prompted by this research and personal use and prescription with Agarikon that I had harvested and subsequently cloned harvested ABOVE 3000ft. elevation/locations. They, as with high elevation/low oxygen exposed Reishi, also showed much higher levels of Agaricin and medicinally significant antibiotic properties, as well.
Western medicine/FDA is just now starting to catch on to what the ancients knew all along. Mushrooms make us more complex and healthier. At least the process is heading in the right direction and Mycophobia in our country is being depleted on a daily basis. Knowledge is power rings true more than ever ;).

I am posting this species as Ganoderma resinaceum due to the fact that macroscopically it does not have the Characteristics of true G. lucidum and more in line with G. resinaceum group(velvety and minutely hirsute-not strictly varnished and glabrous as with true G. lucidum). Many, many online samples/offers of what is touted to be true G. lucidum actually turn out to be either G. sichuanensis, G. resinaceum or even adulterated/mixed samples containing the extremely common and less desired G. applanatum. Regardless of if this was correctly labeled to species(by local company “Myco-up-rrhizal”), the kit is masterfully and sterile practice packaged and the knowledge base for "Myco-uprizzhal’s team is correctly intentioned and the company deserves due praise and business;both here in Olympia, WA and worldwide.

I hope to update this post with growth monitoring, subsequent dehydrating and hopefully a few shots of tea and preparations over the next few weeks.

NOTE: This species does not naturally occur here in Washington State, however I am adding it too my ongoing “Medicinal Mushrooms Of Washington State” species list because I plan to inoculate a local, living Alnus rubra with the mycelial mass/cake after I harvest the fruiting bodies. Will hope to monitor that process and development, as well if possible.

THERE IS NO PERSONAL WEBSITE FOR Myco-up-rrhizal-but I am attaching the Oly Farmer’s market page with listed company’s in an attempt for those interested to contact them for business. I Fully promote and endorse business for this local company and verify their credibility as knowledgeable and responsible growers. http://www.olympiafarmersmarket.com/vendors-1/

UPDATE ON 5/24/18: Yellow guttation(leaking of resin) revealed to that this is indeed Ganoderma resinaceum(as my instincts initially told me). Thanks again to expert Ganoderma specialist, Matthew Schink for his continued advice and helpful information/support. We have assisted one another now for over 5 years and on an annual basis share our passion for fungi and knowledge base with countless groups of aspiring amateur mycologists and experts in the field on both MO and multiple FB forums. He is also an expert farmer/grower and is a vast resource for growing and farming methods(another fact that I am appreciative of and love that we share. I feel truly blessed to get to share my love for all creation and most importantly people and fungi with this wise, young man. Daily O2 exposure for approximately 3 hours in the AM to promote slow, dense growth of fruiting bodies and combat mold proliferation and or insect infestation. Once harvested, I plan to inoculate a local living(albeit, stressed) Alnus rubra or Acer macrophyllum and monitor progress. Multiple locations near TESC campus house perfect examples for monitoring by Mycology programs at TESC in the future(once inoculation is established). I plan to submit applications to the dean in the future for this very purpose. A “hands on” foraging, identification and Myco-farming program that will hopefully be installed, offered and maintained permanently as a BS in Mycology curriculum for the school(as currently, and in the past only 4 credit programs have been offered intermittently to the detriment of hundreds of local and students abroad). I have submitted these requests multiple times in the past. But by prayer and petition I believe that the body of work I have accumulated over the over 10 years of devotion to the field of mycology will finally be recognized for my knowledge base to reach many, many more students in the future. My book “Fungal Freedom-A Guide To Wild Mushrooms Of Washington State” being the primary text for local Washington fungi(in addition to countless texts that are well known and easily accessible). Will continue t monitor this growth and post the harvest and subsequent dehydration methods I use for Ganoderma as time passes and growth increases to full maturity. As with all varnished Ganoderma, the ideal time for harvest is after the caps have planed and flattened, the spore dispersal has occured(and electrostatically covered said caps), and the leading, white growth edge is no longer “marshmallowy” and visible. If local PNW’ers ar monitoring G. oregonense this summer the same rule of thumb applies and should be exercised. That being said, if you wish to try eating Ganoderma for culinary purposes they can also be harvested in the white, marshmallow stage and chewed easily. The sweet, slightly bitter “drying paint” like aroma and flavor are never forgotten and certainly an acquired taste which most who have tried them will admit becomes familiar and addictive. More to come soon!

UPDATED 5/26/18:
Images added of the “nick spots” already completely(or nearly completely) healing over from two days ago. By the evening of the 24th the tiny knife slices I enacted(to show and test guttation color as a key to possible species,macroscopically) were already closing shut and “fluffing” as I like to call it when polypores form rapid, new growth around a stressed area, or as many of you know completely grow around branches or living leaves in the wild. This is certainly a very healthy, strong strain and I look forward to inoculating a wild substrate(either red alder or big leaf maple) at the end of the first fruiting here in Olympia,WA soon. More updates to come-

UPDATE ON 6/5/18. See notes beneath images.

FIRST FLUSH HARVEST DATE 6/28/18- Harvested all fruiting bodies(as spore collection on caps and planing of fruiting body caps is uniform-for the most part). Dehydrating the harvest and re-sealed the bag with approximately a half cup of sterilized water for another harvest. Mycelium is still vibrantly white on the mycelial mass/grow block. Will hope to update shots of new flush in the next three weeks :). SEE ADDED IMAGES OF HARVEST AND RE-SEALING METHOD BELOW.

UPDATE ON 9/11/18: 2nd flush of mature fruiting bodies harvested. See notes under added images in side bar. Poured approximately half a cup of pre-boiled(and cooled, obviously) H2O and tightly sealed the bag against the grow block, yet again, for another flush attempt. My goal was to get a 12 month sustained grow from this single block, but may succumb to mold and other pathogens before succeeding. Either way, 6 months to the day from the companies initial inoculation is more than unheard of for single kits, at least following conventional methods of “airing and spraying” methods, rather than my oxygen deprivation and sterilization/soak technique. Both work, but one gets far longer lasting results. My hope is that next time folks purchase grow kits that they attempt this method and see for themselves the use in it-at least for polypore species(such as Ganoderma, Trametes and Grifola spp.)

9/13/18: Aggressive mycelium has already networked and covered the wounds and harvest locations where I removed fruiting bodies two days ago. See images added in side bar. Just as with bark mulch or on logs where harvest occurs in natural outdoor settings, the mycelium of the organism will rush to heal wounds where damaged and most often will be the site of new fruiting bodies(mushrooms) in the future. This is generally true for all saprophytic and parasitic species of basidiomycetes. Will continue monitoring and hope that pathogens don’t overrun the fruiting block as mushroom/mold season begins. Fingers crossed.
10/2/18-UPDATE OF FLUSH#3: New flush of primordial growth has formed stems(standard red/yellow tones of most young varnished Ganoderma species) where last flushes fruiting bodies were removed. This same phenomenon occurs on wild substrates(logs/dead wood.etc.) in natural habitats during summer months. Will continue to let air exposure occur in short durations each week to combat pathogens(mold/bacteria) from infecting the substrate.
10/30/18: FINAL UPDATE/POST: Flush#3 harvested and photographed due to the mycelium beginning to finally succumb to slight mold infection. After nearly 8 months of growth from initial inoculation and 3 flushes of harvested and dried fruiting bodies, I think it was time. I kept the air exposure low, the exposure to sunlight high throughout the grow process and gave regular waterings of pre-boiled H2O to achieve multiple healthy flushes without infection. Also, I always used universal precautions and Sterilization with alcohol whenever harvesting or handling the grow block directly. After harvesting I transplanted the entire grow block to the back yard and buried it below the topsoil with alder and Doug fir wood chips. We’ll see next July/Aug if a few fruiting bodies decide to flush here in the wild.

Stamnaria sp. growing on horsetail, Equisetum sp.
The specimen most closely matches Stamnaria americana, but the spores are substantially larger, possibly indicating a new species. An anamorph was observed as well, although the conidia were not measured.
Ascopores (9) averaged 31 × 8.7 µm, paraphyses tips were swollen and averaged 5 µm in width, asci (8) averaged 158 × 15.3 µm.
Haelewaters et al. (2018) report Stamnaria americana as having ascospores that are 24-28 × 6.5-7.5 µm.

—

Habitat: abandoned pastures with scattered trees; moderately inclined mountain slope, south-east aspect; relatively warm and dry place; colluvial, calcareous ground, sunny place; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevations 600 m (1.950 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: bark of small branches and twigs of a stand-alone, recently cut down Juglans regia.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča; between villages Soča and Trenta; near Trenta 2b cottage, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comment: Melanelixia subaurifera is a rather small, only a few cm in diameter, adpressed, thin, matt and brown lichen. When dry and growing on brown, rough tree bark it requires some attention to be spotted. When damp, after rain, it becomes olive green and shinier and hence quite conspicuous. It is a widely distributed all over the world and on many places a common lichen.

Habitus of the find seems quite convincing for Melanelixia subaurifera. Optional similar species Melanelixia subargentifera was abandoned because I was able to find neither tiny cortical hairs toward lobe margins and ends (Ref.1) nor purine on the thallus (Ref.5). The lichens were not found on tree’s trunk or at the base of it (Ref.2), but rather on small twigs, which doesn’t match to Melanelixia subargentifera. However, Melanelixia can be easily confused also with brown species of Xanthoparmelia species. Morphological differences are small, however, chemistry is different. My determination is not completely reliable because no chemical tests have been done.

Naming of this species is also to some extent questionable. Index Fungorum keeps the name Melanelixia subaurifera as a synonym of ‘current name’ Melanelia subaurifera, while MycoBank claims the opposite. It seems to me that recent references mostly follow MycoBank.

Lichens of this observation were photographed in damp state. Many specimens were found on this tree.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

Note: original notes have been revised based on further information.

On limestone in mixed forest, on side of ravine. Associated with Caloplaca sp. and Lecidea sp. Thallus C-. Sections through immersed perithecia show round algal cells and hyaline muriform spores. Spores averaged 20 × 12 um (n=24) and a range of 15-25 × 9-15. Although around 6 or 7 perithecia total were examined, all spores fit this description; none were brown. No asci were seen, but one clump of about 8 spores was observed which could have come from an ascus.

The specimen is parasitized by a lichenicolous apothecial parasite, presumed to be Opegrapha pulvinata. See Observation 316951.

results.notes: Scattered on damp lawn. Spore deposit white. I’m debating between this genus and Gymnopus genus.
A few scattered in sandy soil around an oak tree. Spore deposit clear ochre, kind of brownish.
Growing in lawn following generous rain. Scattered, some solitary and some small clusters.
Growing in lawn, small clusters. Light staining upon handling.
Loblolly pine everywhere. Growing in damp
Growing near Spanish Red Oak in damp lawn. Strong blue staining upon touch/damage. Not sure if the last two pictures are the same species, though growing in same vicinity.
Growing in mixed forest/woods on pine needle liter. Likely in the C. tenera group, though could be C. pubescens.
Growing in pine needles, near tree debris. Spore deposit clay/brown. Very distinct umbo on the cap. Fibrillose stipe.

Specimen was growing on older mulch/wood chips. Spore deposit is white. Stipe was twisted and very durable/flexible. I apologize for no pictures of underside, nor the stipe. Was thinking it could be a Melanoleuca species, but the cluster led me to think G. luxurians
Not too positive on this one. Could be Gymnopus species. Deposit was white. Terrestrial and solitary growth between wood chips and damp soil/grass
Growing in fresh mulch, within flower bed. Watered daily. Spore deposit was a tawny/ochre. Twisted stipe makes me believe its Gymnopus or it could also be Agrocybe.

Based on reference above, this species is rare in eastern North America, though I don’t see any other literature about this other than some Hygrophorus species and they don’t seem to fit. Growing in sphagnum moss and pine needle liter. A boggy area, with decent shade. Caps were very sticky and viscid. Striate margin.
Growing directly on wood debris, primarily pine debris. Slightly viscid, striate margin.
Growing near oak, terrestrially (from what I can tell) hence why I’m not positive that it’s a Pluteus species.
Growing right beside Swamp Chestnut Oak (Q. michauxii) in very damp/acidic soil. This sample was relatively dried out and mature. Slight yellowing upon age. Spore deposit white/creamish

Growing near oak, always. Relatively large compared to other Russulas that I find. Grey cap with olivaceous tints (greenish/yellowish) and a slight magenta tint on some different specimens. Stipe kind of has a club shape on some, which leads me to believe that there could be a few different species that look very similar (as is expected with Russulas). Spore deposit heavy cream/pale
Growing between two species of oak (Spanish Red Oak and some type of other oak species. Spore deposit white. Older specimens’ cap very expanded/convex.

Growing in fresh mulch laid on top of older mulch, though two oak trees were within 10 yards away. Irrigation waters daily. Cap predominantly brick-red with yellow hues on cap and flesh. Stipe relatively long compared to most Russulas that I’ve come across, kind of clavate, tapering towards apex. Gills annexed to attached; pulling away from stipe in age. Spore deposit whitish, cream, buff.

Found several growing on a stick on the ground. Deciduous forest in an area that had heavy rain for the week prior.
Two photos show specimens that are flattened. One of these was attached to a hickory nut.
Growing from lawn. Spore deposit is deep purple/brownish. Small cluster. Horse pasture across the road about 200 feet away. Very sturdy stipe.
Mature specimen. Gills very dark purple, almost black. Growing in grass/lawn.
Growing at the base of pine tree (most likely Loblolly pine) in fallen pine needles. Very damp weather, cool (late-December), but warm for the time of the year.
Grows everywhere.
Very slimy/sticky cap. Pine trees everywhere. No ring.
Growing at base of pine trees; very prolific clusters everywhere. Stipe almost bioluminescent. Cap very, very sticky.

results.notes: Me contacto vía facebook un amigo que sabe que me encanta cultivar setos, me mostró las fotos y pensé que muy posiblemente eran psilocybicos…entonces me dirijí de mi casa a esa ubicación me llevo 2 horas llegar hasta ese lugar…cuando llegue, me di cuenta que el barrio era bastante peligroso…entonces llame a esa persona y acordamos un sitio de encuentro. Al encontrarnos el me promete y me asegura que me iba cuidar durante todo el recorrido y me muestra un arma de fuego que llevaba en la cintura…yo solo me encomendaba a los hongos y en lo que creo para que todo saliera bien…en un momento pensé que el quería robarme y por eso me había hecho venir a su barrio, pero solo estaba interesado en que yo le dijera que tipo de hongo era. Así que lo recolecte y lo lleve a casa…cuando llegue se lo mostré a los expertos en este genero y para mi felicidad el me dieron la confirmación del genero y la especie.

results.notes:
Leratiomyces ceres (Agaricales, Strophariaceae) Bogotá, Colombia
https://colombia.inaturalist.org/observations/40641362
https://colombia.inaturalist.org/observations/50875899

Primer registro de esta especie para el país, determinado el 5/06/2016 por Chivatá Teodoro y Arias Camila, en el Humedal La Conejera Bogotá, Colombia.

Basidioma estipitado, lignicola, principalmente gregario, en ocasiones solitario o cespitado, no higrofano, el Píleo mide entre 5 a 7 cm de diámetro, hemisférico en un principio, luego pasa a ser plano convexo con el centro umbonado, orbicular (vista apical). Margen recto, entero y ligeramente ondulado, de superficie glabra, viscida y brillosa, que luego pasa a ser seca y opaca, de color rojo que tiende a oscurecerse hacia el borde, con escamas fasciculadas originadas por restos del velo universal que forma un círculo a modo de collar cerca del borde. Himenio con lamelas y lamélulas, se encuentran próximas entre sí (apretadas), adnadas a ligeramente uncinadas, anchas, de borde liso, lamélulas atenuadas, de color café claro principio, después gris violáceo y finalmente púrpura negruzco, arista entera, blanquecina. Contexto homegeneo y hueco. Esporada de color marron oscuro.

Estípite de 4-8 cm de largo x 0.4-0.5 cm de ancho, cilíndrico, central, sub-bulboso y con tomento basal con cordones miceliares (rizomorfos), de color blanco con zonas de color naranja rojizo que se intensifica con el tiempo, pruinoso. Se engrosa ligeramente hacia la base. De consistencia fibrosa. Sin olor o sabor apreciable. Basidiosporas elipsoidales, lisas, de paredes gruesas, con poro germinal.

Primer registro de esta especie para Colombia. Segun Vasco-Palacios AM, Franco-Molano AE. 2013, la familia Strophariaceae esta representada por las siguientes especies:

Hypholoma sublateritium (Schaeff.) Quél.
Hypholoma subviride (Berk. & M.A. Curtis) Dennis.

Melanotus cassiaecolor (Berk.) Singer.
Melanotus dumontii Singer

Naematoloma udum (Pers.) P. Karst..
Pholiota aberrans A.H.
Pholiota apiahyna Speg.
Pholiota naucorioides Singer.
Pholiota privigna (Speg.) Singer.
Pleuroflammula squarrulosa Singer.

results.notes: Growing beside Quercus michauxii. Very viscid/sticky when wet. Margin striate/strongly tuberculate. Cuticle peeling about halfway. Gills attached, slightly notched; forking present near stipe, white/close. Stipe firm, older specimens’ stipe becoming crumbly/hollow. Stipe clavate, sometimes tapering at base, exhibiting brown bruising. Spore deposit whitish/pale cream.
Growing in lawn. Small little groups (3-4 at most). Spore deposit brown.

Crust-like fungus that, upon closer inspection, was clearly not a typical corticioid fungus. The fungus is an anamorph with a crust like, brownish, effused structure growing on a decorticated stick, with a spreading white fibrilose margine. The crust part consisted of a thin brown layer that cracked, revealing a dark reddish trama composed of balls. Growing from the crust base were Phleogena-like stalked “puffballs”. Under the microscope, I saw that these were actually conidiogenous structures. The spores ranged in size from 3-5 × 5 µm and were inamyloid.
